name: q14_1
probTex: Using contour integration, find the value of\n\[\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{dt}{\cos(t)-2}.\]
solnTex:
Recall Euler's formula $e^{it}=\cos(t)+i\sin(t)$. From this we get the identity
\[\cos(t)= rac{e^{it}+e^{-it}}{2}.\]
Then we can rewrite our integral as
\[\int_0^{2\pi} rac{dt}{\cos(t)-2}=\int_0^{2\pi} rac{dt}{ rac{e^{it}+e^{-it}}{2}-2}=\int_0^{2\pi} rac{2dt}{e^{it}+e^{-it}-4}=\int_0^{2\pi} rac{2e^{it}dt}{e^{2it}+1-4e^{it}}.\]
Now we make the substitution $z=e^{it}$, so the path $\gamma$ becomes the unit circle, to obtain
\[\int_\gamma rac{ rac{2}{i}dz}{z^2+1-4z}=-2i\int_\gamma rac{dz}{z^2-4z+1}.\]
The poles of this integrand occur at $z= rac{1}{2}(4\pm\sqrt{16-4})=2\pm\sqrt{3}$. Only $2-\sqrt 3$ is encircled by $\gamma$, so we use Cauchy's integral formula to obtain
\[\int_\gamma rac{1/(z-(2+\sqrt 3))}{z-(2-\sqrt 3)}dz=2\pi i rac{1}{2-\sqrt 3-2-\sqrt 3}= rac{\pi i}{-\sqrt 3}.\]
Considering the $-2i$ coefficient from earlier gives us that our answer is
\[ rac{-2\pi}{\sqrt 3}.\]
